questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-month history of persistent cough productive of white phlegm. He coughs consistently throughout the day, and he has not noticed any particular triggers that make it worse. He has also recently experienced some shortness of breath with exertion. He has not had any weight loss, fever, or chills. He had similar symptoms last year, which lasted about 6 months. He has hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine. He has worked in construction for the past 10 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an end-expiratory wheeze throughout all lung zones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is mediated by a combined type III and type IV hypersensitivity reaction to an inhaled environmental allergen, typically organic particles in the course of occupational exposure (e.g., farmer's lung). Although the subacute form can also manifest with productive cough and dyspnea, this patient's symptoms are constant and do not have an identifiable trigger, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Smokers are actually at reduced risk of developing this type of pneumonitis because they have a decreased immune response to new inhaled antigens.

B) INCORRECT:

Asthma can also manifest with chronic cough (often dry), dyspnea, and end-expiratory wheezing on examination. However, it typically affects younger patients (commonly children and teenagers), has an identifiable trigger, and is much more sudden in onset and episodic than this patient's history suggests. This patient's productive cough and significant smoking history make another option more likely.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis, a subtype of COPD, is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of productive cough for 4–6 months each year for the past 2 years. The vast majority of cases of COPD can be attributed to smoking, and patients with ≥ 20–30 pack years have an 80–90% lifetime risk of developing COPD. Occupational exposure to organic/nonorganic dust can also significantly increase risk. Dyspnea will continue to become more severe until it is present even at rest. Smokers should, therefore, be counseled about cessation to reduce the rate of respiratory decline.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can also present with a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and wheezing on auscultation. This patient's smoking history and occupational exposure do put him at risk of developing a bronchial obstruction. However, the sputum in this condition is typically mucopurulent, not white, as a result of an underlying local infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis can manifest with nonspecific symptoms such as chronic cough and exertional dyspnea. Having worked in construction, it is possible that this patient has had occupational exposure to asbestos, and his smoking history would further increase the risk of disease progression. However, there is still a very long latent period, 15–20 years after significant exposure, before any signs of disease appear. Furthermore, asbestosis typically manifests with end-inspiratory rales rather than wheezes on auscultation.
questions.hint: Pulmonary function testing would likely show a decreased FEV1/FVC (< 70%) ratio.

questions.text: A previously healthy 60-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. He does not experience shortness of breath at rest. He also occasionally has a dry cough. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62% after bronchodilator inhalation, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is also a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occasionally occur. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease; the TLC would therefore be decreased, and FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased. Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than end-expiratory wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; total lung capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

C) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with progressively worsening dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, a prolonged expiratory phase, and spirometry findings of a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, a decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). Smoking is responsible for over 90% of cases of COPD. Emphysema-predominant COPD can manifest with cachexia (due to increased work of breathing) and an occasional dry cough. Decreased DLCO levels indicate a decreased surface area for air exchange from the destruction of the alveoli present in emphysema.

The patient has an FEV1 between 50 and 80% of the predicted value, which means he has moderate COPD (GOLD class 2) and should therefore be treated with inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists such as salmeterol or formoterol. Patients with COPD should receive the pneumococcal vaccine every 5–6 years and the influenza vaccine annually, and should also be counseled on smoking cessation.

Key learning point: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is characterized by progressive dyspnea, obstructive spirometry (decreased FEV1/FVC), increased total lung capacity, decreased DLCO, and is most commonly caused by long-term smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. The TLC may also be increased in some patients. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1 (< 80% of predicted value), decreased FEV1:FVC (< 70%), and increased total lung capacity (TLC) (> 120% of predicted). A chest x-ray of patients with this diagnosis often shows hyperlucency of the lung fields and bilateral diaphragmatic flattening.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and was recently discharged from the hospital for an exacerbation. His mobility is still severely limited by dyspnea and fatigue. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. His medications include inhaled daily budesonide, formoterol, and tiotropium bromide plus ipratropium/albuterol as needed. His oxygen saturation on room air ranges from 84–90% at rest. Auscultation of the lungs discloses expiratory wheezing and a prolonged expiratory phase. Distant heart sounds but no murmurs are heard. Pulmonary function testing shows an FEV1 of 27% of predicted. Which of the following steps in management is most likely to prolong survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with COPD, continuous long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) reduces the risk of developing pulmonary hypertension and prevents complications that may arise from pulmonary hypertension. Tobacco cessation and LTOT are the interventions with the greatest impact on survival in patients with COPD. Lung volume reduction surgery may also improve survival in select patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary rehabilitation (e.g., breathing exercises, such as pursed lip breathing) can improve pulmonary function, decrease symptoms of COPD, and decrease the risk of acute rehospitalization. However, pulmonary rehabilitation has not consistently been shown to prolong survival in patients with COPD. A different measure is likely to have a bigger impact on this patient's survival.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled salmeterol is a long-acting beta-2 agonist (LABA) indicated to treat moderate to severe COPD (FEV1 < 80% of predicted). However, this patient is already treated with formoterol, and an additional LABA is unlikely to provide further benefit. Moreover, inhaled salmeterol does not prolong survival in patients with COPD.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against pneumococcal infection is recommended in all adults aged ≥ 50 years and younger adults with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., individuals with chronic lung disease). While pneumococcal vaccination can decrease the risk of community-acquired pneumonia and COPD exacerbations and should be included in the routine management of this patient, it has not been shown to significantly improve survival in patients with COPD.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled steroids, such as fluticasone, are recommended for severe COPD (FEV1< 50% of predicted). However, this patient is already treated with an inhaled steroid (budesonide), and an additional steroid is unlikely to provide further benefit. Moreover, inhaled steroids do not prolong survival in patients with COPD.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

C) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

D) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).
questions.hint: This patient's history of dyspnea and productive cough combined with a decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity make chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 2-day history of worsening shortness of breath. During the past week, she had a runny nose, mild sore throat, and a low-grade fever. She also has had a cough occasionally productive of sputum for the past 2 years. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezes with a prolonged expiratory phase are heard over both lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.33


PCO2
53 mm Hg


PO2

68 mm Hg


An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of bilateral lung fields and flattening of the diaphragm. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A decrease in urinary HCO3- excretion is a compensatory measure in response to hypercapnia and chronic respiratory acidosis, which often occur in patients with COPD as a result of expiratory airway collapse and respiratory muscle fatigue. The proximal convoluted tubules reabsorb HCO3-, improving the buffer capacity of the serum against lower pH. The distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts in the kidneys also increase excretion of H+ (in the form of H2PO4‑ and NH4+), raising the blood pH to compensate for respiratory acidosis.
Image Description:

This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

B) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary pH caused by the increased renal tubular excretion of HCO3- occurs as a compensatory mechanism in individuals with respiratory alkalosis. This patient's decreased arterial pH and increased PCO2, however, indicate respiratory acidosis, in which the compensatory mechanism is a decrease (not an increase) in urinary pH.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased serum anion gap occurs in high anion gap metabolic acidosis because of an accumulation of unmeasured ions (e.g., ammonium, butyrate, citrate, lactate). In respiratory acidosis, the serum anion gap typically remains unchanged.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypokalemia occurs in alkalemia through a shift of K+ ions from plasma into cellular compartments. Extracellular K+ exchanges with intracellular H+ as a compensatory mechanism to lower pH levels. In this patient with acidemia, hyperkalemia would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased urinary chloride concentration occurs in conditions that cause chloride-depletion metabolic alkalosis such as excessive vomiting or diuretic overuse. Respiratory acidosis is not associated with significant changes in urinary chloride concentration.
questions.hint: In this chronic smoker, worsening shortness of breath following an upper respiratory infection suggests an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Arterial blood gas analysis showing decreased pH and increased PCO2 is consistent with respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with advanced COPD (FEV1 25% predicted) smokes heavily and has a PaO2 of 50 mmHg. Which pair of interventions prolongs survival in severe COPD?

choices.text: High-dose inhaled corticosteroids and pulmonary rehabilitation
Smoking cessation and long-term oxygen therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose inhaled corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation and exacerbation frequency but do not prolong survival in advanced COPD. Pulmonary rehabilitation improves exercise tolerance and quality of life but does not extend life. These interventions do not address the hypoxemia-related mortality risk in severe COPD.

B) CORRECT:

Smoking cessation is crucial in slowing the progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) by halting the inflammatory process and preventing further decline in lung function. Long-term oxygen therapy is indicated for patients with severe COPD and chronic hypoxemia (PaO2 ≤55 mmHg or SaO2 ≤88%). It improves survival by enhancing oxygenation, reducing pulmonary vasoconstriction, and decreasing the risk of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular strain. Clinical trials have shown that these interventions prolong survival and improve quality of life in patients with severe COPD.

Key learning point: In severe COPD, smoking cessation and supplemental oxygen therapy for chronic hypoxemia are interventions that can improve survival.

C) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation slows COPD progression and improves survival. Inhaled corticosteroids reduce exacerbations but do not alter mortality. In severe COPD with hypoxemia, interventions like long-term oxygen therapy, which directly improve gas exchange, are necessary for survival benefit.

D) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive ventilation is used for acute exacerbations or chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure but lacks evidence for long-term survival benefit in advanced COPD. Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors reduce exacerbations in chronic bronchitis but do not prolong life. Neither intervention addresses the hypoxemia-related mortality risk.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath on exertion and an increasing daily productive cough with occasional wheezing over the last 8 months. He has a 20-year history of smoking. He experiences mild respiratory distress with moderate exertion and denies orthopnea or chest pain. He has no significant occupational exposures. Physical examination reveals prolonged expiration with mild end-expiratory wheezes. Laboratory results show normal hemoglobin level and normal serum alpha-1 antitrypsin concentration (see reports).

Oxygen saturation
98% at rest


Arterial blood gas: Normal
Chest X-ray: Clear lung fields without hyperinflation

Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis involves chronic productive cough with large amounts of purulent sputum and recurrent infections, often with radiographic evidence of bronchial dilation. The patient's clear chest X-ray and absence of recurrent infections or systemic signs make bronchiectasis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's long history of smoking, progressive exertional dyspnea, and chronic productive cough suggest chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). COPD includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema, where smoking leads to airway inflammation, remodeling, and mucus hypersecretion. Physical examination findings, such as prolonged expiration and wheezing, indicate airflow limitation. Normal chest X-ray and arterial blood gas results are consistent with early-stage COPD. The normal serum alpha-1 antitrypsin level excludes a genetic cause, reinforcing smoking as the primary etiology.

Key learning point: A history of smoking, shortness of breath, productive cough, and wheezing are indicative of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), even if chest X-ray and arterial blood gases are normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Asthma typically presents with episodic wheezing, cough, and reversible airway obstruction, often starting at a younger age. The patient's age, chronic progressive symptoms, and smoking history are more indicative of COPD.

D) INCORRECT:

Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced lung volumes and inspiratory abnormalities. The patient's smoking history, prolonged expiration, and wheezing suggest an obstructive process. Normal arterial blood gas values and clear chest X-ray argue against restrictive pathology, such as fibrosis or interstitial changes.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with COPD presents to the Outpatient Clinic concerned about tracking his disease progression. He has a 50 pack-year smoking history and reports increased cough and sputum production. On examination, he is comfortable at rest with mild wheezing. He is scheduled for pulmonary function testing.
Which parameter from pulmonary function testing is most reliable for monitoring the long-term progression of his disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total lung capacity (TLC) measures the maximum air volume in the lungs after maximal inspiration. In COPD, TLC is often elevated due to air trapping and hyperinflation. However, it reflects static lung volume rather than dynamic airflow limitation, which is more relevant to COPD progression. Variability in patient effort and testing technique can also affect TLC, limiting its reliability for long-term monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Forced vital capacity (FVC) measures the total volume of air exhaled forcefully after full inspiration. FVC reduction is not specific to airway obstruction and can occur in restrictive lung diseases. It is influenced by air trapping and patient effort, making it less reliable for monitoring airflow limitation in COPD progression.

C) CORRECT:

Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) is the most reliable parameter for monitoring chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) progression. It measures the volume of air exhaled in the first second of a forced expiration, reflecting airflow limitation. In COPD, progressive airway narrowing and loss of elastic recoil lead to a decline in FEV1, correlating with symptom severity and exacerbation risk. Longitudinal FEV1 assessment helps evaluate pulmonary function decline, differentiate disease-specific changes from normal aging, and tailor management strategies. Its reproducibility and sensitivity to lung changes make it essential for disease monitoring and prognostication.

Key learning point: FEV1 is the most useful marker for monitoring the progression of COPD, as it reflects the severity of airflow obstruction and changes over time.

D) INCORRECT:

Diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) assesses gas exchange and alveolar-capillary membrane integrity. While reduced DLCO indicates alveolar destruction in emphysema, it is less reliable for tracking COPD progression, especially in chronic bronchitis, where airflow obstruction predominates. DLCO can be influenced by hemoglobin levels, technical issues, and recent smoking, limiting its utility for consistent long-term monitoring.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath despite using a combination of inhaled bronchodilators. He reports frequent nocturnal awakenings due to breathing difficulty. He has a 30-year smoking history. Examination shows mild cyanosis and bilateral lower extremity edema. The forced expiratory volume in 1 second is 38% of the predicted value. Two recent arterial blood gas analyses at rest show PaO2 values of 7.1 kPa and 6.9 kPa.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is indicated in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients with resting hypoxemia, defined as a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 7.3 kPa (approximately 55 mm Hg) or lower, or oxygen saturation below 88%. This patient has PaO2 values of 7.1 kPa and 6.9 kPa, indicating chronic hypoxemia. LTOT, administered for at least 15 hours daily, improves survival, exercise performance, and symptoms of hypoxemia. The presence of mild cyanosis and bilateral lower extremity edema suggests possible cor pulmonale, further supporting the need for LTOT.

Key learning point: Long-term oxygen therapy is indicated in COPD patients with two arterial blood gas measurements showing pO2 less than 7.3 kPa, indicating severe resting hypoxemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids reduce exacerbation frequency in COPD but do not address hypoxemia. This patient has severe airflow limitation and hypoxemia, with symptoms like cyanosis and edema. Increasing corticosteroid dosage will not improve oxygenation, which requires interventions like long-term oxygen therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

High-resolution chest CT scans are useful for assessing parenchymal lung disease and emphysematous changes, but they are not necessary for immediate management in this patient. The clinical presentation, including a history of smoking, reduced FEV1, and hypoxemia, indicates advanced COPD. The primary management focus is addressing hypoxemia, not further imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic oral antibiotics are used in COPD patients with recurrent infective exacerbations or bronchiectasis. This patient shows no signs of active or recurrent infections. The focus should be on managing chronic hypoxemia and its complications, not on antibiotics, which carry risks of resistance and adverse effects.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea over the past two years. He reports a chronic cough producing scant sputum. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. On auscultation, breath sounds are distant with prolonged expiration (see report).
Pulmonary function tests: Reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, increased total lung capacity, decreased vital capacity compared to predicted values
Which of the following best explains these pulmonary function findings?

choices.text: Air trapping from small airway collapse reducing effective exhalation
Increased elasticity of alveolar walls leading to improved airflow
Excessive mucus production causing restrictive ventilation
Pleural thickening reducing lung expansion uniformly

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The pulmonary function test findings indicate an obstructive ventilatory defect, characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Chronic exposure to irritants like cigarette smoke leads to inflammation and structural changes in small airways, causing loss of elastic recoil and premature airway closure during expiration. This results in air trapping, which limits effective exhalation, increases total lung capacity, and reduces vital capacity. The decreased FEV1/FVC ratio reflects persistent expiratory flow limitation, a hallmark of COPD pathophysiology.

Key learning point: COPD is characterized by a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, increased total lung capacity due to hyperinflation, and decreased vital capacity due to air trapping.

B) INCORRECT:

In obstructive pulmonary disease, such as COPD, there is a reduction in alveolar wall elasticity due to destruction of alveolar septa. This loss of elastic recoil impairs air expulsion during expiration, contributing to air trapping and increased total lung capacity. Increased elasticity is not consistent with the patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive mucus production is associated with obstructive defects, not restrictive ventilation. In restrictive lung diseases, total lung capacity is reduced. The patient's increased total lung capacity and decreased FEV1/FVC ratio indicate an obstructive process, not a restrictive one.

D) INCORRECT:

Pleural thickening typically results in a restrictive pattern with reduced lung volumes and a maintained or increased FEV1/FVC ratio. The patient's obstructive defect, with reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and increased total lung capacity, is more consistent with emphysema, not pleural thickening.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man with severe COPD presents with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and has been hospitalized multiple times over the past year for exacerbations. He is on maximal inhaled bronchodilator therapy. He appears fatigued and uses accessory muscles to breathe. Examination shows hyperinflated lungs (see lab result).

Oxygen saturation
85% at rest



Test
Result
Normal Values



Arterial blood gas




 PO₂
6.7 kPa
10.6 - 14.2 kPa



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic hypoxemia significantly impacts morbidity and mortality. This patient exhibits severe hypoxemia with an oxygen saturation of 85% and a PaO₂ of 6.7 kPa, necessitating supplemental oxygen. Long-term continuous home oxygen therapy improves survival by maintaining tissue oxygenation, decreasing pulmonary vasoconstriction, and reducing right heart strain. It also minimizes complications such as pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale, addressing the systemic effects of chronic hypoxemia.

Key learning point: Long-term oxygen therapy is the only treatment shown to improve survival in patients with advanced COPD and severe resting hypoxemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation and exacerbation frequency in COPD, especially with frequent exacerbations or an asthmatic component. This patient has severe hypoxemia and lung hyperinflation, indicating impaired gas exchange rather than reversible inflammation. Increasing corticosteroids does not address hypoxemia or ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

C) INCORRECT:

Roflumilast, a phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor, reduces exacerbation frequency in COPD, particularly with chronic bronchitis. However, it does not address acute oxygenation issues. This patient requires immediate intervention for severe hypoxemia, not long-term exacerbation reduction.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic azithromycin can reduce exacerbations in COPD patients with frequent exacerbations due to its anti-inflammatory properties. However, it does not address severe hypoxemia, which is the primary issue in this patient with an oxygen saturation of 85% and low arterial PO₂. Azithromycin does not improve acute oxygenation or address chronic hypoxemia.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and intermittent wheezing for the past year. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and currently uses a short-acting bronchodilator as needed, but requires it multiple times daily. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds with a prolonged expiratory phase. Recent spirometry shows an FEV1 at 60% of predicted. He is seeking better symptom control.

Oxygen saturation
95% on room air

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Combination inhaled corticosteroid and long-acting beta-2 agonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Short-acting bronchodilators are suitable for mild, infrequent symptoms. However, this patient requires multiple daily doses, indicating moderate COPD. Sole reliance on short-acting bronchodilators does not provide the sustained relief needed for his persistent symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids are not first-line monotherapy for COPD due to limited efficacy on neutrophil-driven inflammation. They are more effective in asthma. In COPD, they are reserved for frequent exacerbations or specific biomarkers, neither of which is present here.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms and spirometry results indicate moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Long-acting bronchodilators, such as long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs) or long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMAs), provide sustained airway dilation, improving respiratory function and reducing the need for rescue inhalers. Pulmonary rehabilitation, which includes exercise training and education, enhances exercise tolerance and quality of life. This approach aligns with guidelines recommending escalation from short-acting to long-acting bronchodilators and rehabilitation for patients with persistent symptoms.

Key learning point: In moderate COPD with moderate symptoms, the management includes a long-acting bronchodilator and pulmonary rehabilitation, with a short-acting bronchodilator as needed for symptom relief.

D) INCORRECT:

While LABAs are essential in COPD management, adding inhaled corticosteroids is typically reserved for frequent exacerbations or significant eosinophilic inflammation. This patient has moderate COPD without frequent exacerbations, making long-acting bronchodilator monotherapy more appropriate.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents for follow-up. He has a 40-year smoking history and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Over the past year, he has been hospitalized twice for acute exacerbations requiring intravenous corticosteroids. He currently uses a tiotropium inhaler daily and a short-acting beta-agonist as needed. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds bilaterally but no acute distress (see report).
Pulmonary function testing: FEV1 is 35% of predicted
What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Stop tiotropium and rely on short-acting bronchodilators
Inhaled steroid plus a long-acting beta-agonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic macrolide therapy is reserved for patients with frequent exacerbations despite optimal inhaled therapy. This patient has not yet maximized inhaled therapy with a long-acting beta-agonist and inhaled corticosteroid, making macrolide therapy premature.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic oral corticosteroids are not recommended for stable COPD management due to significant side effects, including osteoporosis and hyperglycemia, without proven long-term benefits. They are primarily used for short-term management during acute exacerbations.

C) INCORRECT:

Tiotropium, a long-acting muscarinic antagonist, is crucial for maintenance therapy in advanced COPD. It provides sustained bronchodilation and reduces exacerbations. Relying solely on short-acting bronchodilators would increase symptom burden and exacerbation risk.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's severely reduced forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and history of frequent exacerbations necessitate an escalation in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) management. Adding an inhaled corticosteroid to a long-acting beta-agonist is recommended for patients with severe airflow limitation and frequent exacerbations. This combination targets airway inflammation and provides sustained bronchodilation, reducing exacerbation frequency and improving lung function. It is particularly beneficial for patients who remain symptomatic despite long-acting anticholinergic therapy, such as tiotropium.

Key learning point: In patients with severe COPD and frequent exacerbations, a combination of a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) and an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) is recommended to reduce exacerbations and improve lung function.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with six months of progressively worsening cough and exertional dyspnea to the clinic. He has a 45-year history of heavy smoking. He often produces small amounts of whitish sputum but denies hemoptysis. He has an unintentional 3-kg weight loss during this time. Examination shows increased anteroposterior chest diameter and scattered wheezes. Vital signs are stable (see report).
Chest X-ray: Hyperinflated lungs; no masses
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT scan evaluates lung parenchyma in interstitial lung disease or atypical emphysema. In suspected COPD, spirometry is the initial test to assess functional impairment. CT is reserved for uncertain diagnoses or structural complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy evaluates endobronchial lesions or abnormalities, such as hemoptysis or masses. In this patient, the chest x-ray shows hyperinflation without masses, suggesting emphysema. Bronchoscopy is not indicated without focal findings or symptoms like hemoptysis.

C) CORRECT:

Spirometry is the primary diagnostic tool for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), as it measures airflow limitation, a key feature of the disease. It assesses lung function by evaluating the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and the forced vital capacity (FVC). A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, typically less than 0.70 post-bronchodilator, confirms persistent airflow obstruction. This test not only confirms the diagnosis but also helps stage the disease severity, guiding management. The patient's chronic cough, progressive dyspnea, smoking history, and hyperinflation on chest x-ray support the use of spirometry for evaluation.

Key learning point: In a patient with chronic cough and dyspnea with a significant smoking history, spirometry is the appropriate next step to evaluate for obstructive or restrictive lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas analysis assesses oxygenation and ventilation, particularly in acute decompensation. However, in stable patients with suspected COPD, spirometry is preferred to confirm airflow obstruction. ABG is not the initial diagnostic tool in stable patients without signs of acute respiratory compromise.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with a productive cough for five months each year over the past two years. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and mild dyspnea on exertion. He reports daily sputum production, occasionally streaked with blood. Scattered wheezes and coarse crackles are heard on auscultation.

Oxygen saturation
94% on room air

Which historical feature most strongly supports the classic definition of this patient’s primary condition?

choices.text: Nighttime breathlessness relieved by a short-acting bronchodilator
Productive cough for at least three months annually over two successive years
Daily sputum production lasting less than three months per year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nighttime breathlessness relieved by a bronchodilator is characteristic of asthma, which involves reversible airway obstruction. Chronic bronchitis involves chronic inflammation and mucus hypersecretion, with less reversible airflow limitation.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is defined by a productive cough lasting at least three months per year for two consecutive years. This definition reflects the chronic airway inflammation and mucus hypersecretion caused by irritants like tobacco smoke. The patient's history of a productive cough for five months each year aligns with this definition, distinguishing chronic bronchitis from acute respiratory conditions.

Key learning point: Chronic bronchitis is characterized by a productive cough lasting for at least 3 months in 2 consecutive years, often associated with a history of smoking and symptoms such as wheezing and crackles.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hemoptysis requiring antibiotics suggests an acute infectious or inflammatory process, such as bronchiectasis or pneumonia, rather than chronic bronchitis. Chronic bronchitis is characterized by a prolonged productive cough, not significant hemoptysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Daily sputum production for less than three months per year does not meet the criteria for chronic bronchitis, which requires a productive cough for at least three months annually over two years. Shorter durations suggest transient infections or acute bronchitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of gradually worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years, but quit 8 years ago. His pulse is 72/min, blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, he has an increased anteroposterior chest diameter and diminished breath sounds on auscultation. Chest x-ray reveals widened intercostal spaces, a flattened diaphragm, and bilateral basilar hyperlucency. Which one of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an interstitial lung disease that is most commonly idiopathic in origin. Occupational hazards (e.g., silicosis), chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., bleomycin), smoking, and infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) significantly increase the risk of progressing to irreversible fibrosis. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of IPF.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans, which occurs as a result of repeated cycles of inflammation and scarring in the small airways, is typically due to inhalation of toxic fumes, graft-versus-host disease in lung transplant patients, or chronic lung infections. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of bronchiolitis obliterans.

C) INCORRECT:

A1AD does not lead to higher rates of lung cancer. Smoking is the single most important risk factor in the development of lung cancer, and this patient is already benefiting from significant risk reduction having quit 8 years ago with only a relatively short 5-pack-year history.

D) CORRECT:

About 40% of patients with A1AD develop significant liver damage and cirrhosis, which are common precursors to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), although progression to HCC can also occur in the absence of cirrhosis in these patients. In contrast to the enhanced protease activity leading to excessive breakdown of elastin that causes early-onset emphysema, liver disease is thought to occur due to toxic accumulation of the misfolded alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in hepatic tissue, which significantly increases the risk of liver damage, cirrhosis, and HCC.

Key learning point: Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency increases the risk of early-onset emphysema and hepatocellular carcinoma due to toxic accumulation of misfolded protein in the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

ANCA-associated vasculitis with antibodies directed against either myeloperoxidase (MPO-ANCA) or proteinase-3 (PR3-ANCA) typically involves small vessels. Because alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) inhibits PR3 activity, current hypotheses suggest that the lack of AAT in patients with A1AD leads to excessive PR3-mediated tissue destruction, and in turn, is more likely to induce an autoimmune response. However, there is currently no evidence to support an increased risk of developing ANCA-positive vasculitis in individuals with A1AD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with worsening dyspnea and signs of emphysema (barrel chest, diminished breath sounds, lung hyperinflation on x-ray). Given his young age (< 50 years), alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (A1AD) is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. He does not have shortness of breath at rest and occasionally has a dry cough. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. On lung auscultation, there is a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62% after bronchodilator inhalation, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is also a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occasionally occur. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease; the TLC would therefore be decreased, and FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased. Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than end-expiratory wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; total lung capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. The TLC may also be increased in some patients. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with progressively worsening dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, a prolonged expiratory phase, and spirometry findings of a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, a decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). Smoking is responsible for over 90% of cases of COPD. Emphysema-predominant COPD can manifest with cachexia (due to increased work of breathing) and an occasional dry cough. Decreased DLCO levels indicate a decreased surface area for air exchange from the destruction of the alveoli present in emphysema.

The patient has an FEV1 between 50 and 80% of the predicted value, which means he has moderate COPD (GOLD class 2) and should therefore be treated with inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists such as salmeterol or formoterol. Patients with COPD should receive the pneumococcal vaccine every 5–6 years and the influenza vaccine annually, and should also be counseled on smoking cessation.

Key learning point: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is characterized by progressive dyspnea, obstructive spirometry (decreased FEV1/FVC), increased total lung capacity, decreased DLCO, and is strongly associated with a history of smoking.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1 (< 80% of predicted value), decreased FEV1:FVC (< 70%), and increased total lung capacity (TLC) (> 120% of predicted). A chest x-ray of patients with this diagnosis often shows hyperlucency of the lung fields and bilateral diaphragmatic flattening.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic because of increasing shortness of breath and a dry cough over the past 6 months. She has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On chest auscultation, there are scattered expiratory wheezes in both lung fields. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. Her diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 42% of predicted. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. On auscultation of the chest, you hear bilateral end-expiratory wheezing. Pulmonary function tests show a total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which one of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).

C) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

D) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

Key learning point: Smoking cessation is the most effective intervention to slow the decline in lung function in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea over 2 years and chronic productive cough. He reports increasing fatigue and ankle swelling over the past month. On examination, he has pursed-lip breathing, barrel chest, and diminished breath sounds bilaterally. Vital signs are BP 115/85; P, 90; R, 24; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); oxygen saturation, 88% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is the most appropriate next step based on this patient's oxygen saturation of 88% and signs suggesting advanced COPD with possible cor pulmonale. ABG should be obtained in patients with oxygen saturation < 92% to assess for hypoxemic and hypercapnic respiratory failure and to guide oxygen therapy decisions.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest CT is not routinely indicated for COPD diagnosis or management. While chest imaging may be considered to evaluate for alternative diagnoses or complications, another step takes priority based on this patient's clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

While echocardiogram may eventually be helpful to assess for right heart failure, which is suggested by this patient's ankle swelling, another step in management is more urgently needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin screening is recommended for all patients with COPD but is not the immediate priority in this patient with hypoxemia and signs of decompensation.

E) INCORRECT:

While sputum culture is used in the workup of acute exacerbation of COPD, another step in management takes priority based on this patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath and a chronic productive cough. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Physical examination shows a barrel-shaped chest, decreased breath sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase. His condition is primarily caused by irreversible airway obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for the lung damage seen in this patient?

choices.text: Excessive alveolar wall destruction by neutrophil elastase
Aberrant wound healing leading to fibroblast proliferation
Impaired chloride transport causing viscous airway secretions

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, specifically the emphysematous component. The primary mechanism involves an imbalance between proteases and antiproteases. Chronic exposure to cigarette smoke incites an inflammatory response, recruiting neutrophils and macrophages to the lungs. These activated neutrophils release neutrophil elastase, a potent enzyme that degrades elastin in the alveolar walls. Normally, alpha-1 antitrypsin neutralizes elastase, but tobacco smoke both increases the inflammatory cell load and oxidatively inactivates alpha-1 antitrypsin. This leads to unchecked proteolytic destruction of the alveolar septa, resulting in loss of elastic recoil, airway collapse during expiration, and the formation of large, non-functional airspaces (emphysema).

B) INCORRECT:

This mechanism describes a type I hypersensitivity reaction, which is the hallmark of allergic asthma. Although asthma causes shortness of breath and airway obstruction, the obstruction is typically reversible and is not associated with the barrel chest in this patient. This patient's extensive smoking history and irreversible changes are not characteristic of asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

This process describes the pathophysiology of interstitial lung diseases, such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. These conditions are restrictive, not obstructive, and are characterized by scarring and stiffening of the lung parenchyma. Although patients with interstitial lung disease present with dyspnea, physical examination would more likely show bibasilar crackles, and pulmonary function tests would show a restrictive pattern, which contrasts with this patient's obstructive features.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the mechanism for cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which typically results from left-sided heart failure. Although it causes dyspnea, the presentation is often more acute and is associated with findings such as orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bibasilar crackles on examination. This patient's chronic history, productive cough, and signs of air trapping are not characteristic of pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the underlying genetic defect in cystic fibrosis (CF), which is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. Although CF leads to obstructive lung disease and chronic cough, it is an autosomal recessive disorder that typically presents in childhood or early adulthood. It would be an extremely unlikely new diagnosis in a 68-year-old individual with a significant smoking history.
questions.hint: Chronic inflammation from cigarette smoke can disrupt the normal balance between enzymes that break down lung tissue and the proteins that protect it.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 1-year history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, now occurring with minimal exertion such as walking to his mailbox. He reports a chronic morning cough productive of white sputum for the past several years. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. On examination, his respiratory rate is 22/min. He has an increased anteroposterior chest diameter and a prolonged expiratory phase. Breath sounds are diminished throughout all lung fields without crackles or wheezes. Cardiac examination is unremarkable, and his jugular venous pressure is normal. There is trace bilateral pitting edema of the ankles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's progressive dyspnea on exertion and peripheral edema are consistent with congestive heart failure. However, the unremarkable cardiac examination, normal jugular venous pressure, and absence of crackles (rales) on lung auscultation argue against significant fluid overload or pulmonary edema. The prominent pulmonary findings of hyperinflation are not typical of heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease can manifest with progressive dyspnea. However, it is a restrictive process, typically associated with a dry, nonproductive cough and fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation. This patient's productive cough and physical examination findings of prolonged expiration and increased anteroposterior diameter are inconsistent with a primary restrictive lung disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His extensive smoking history is the most significant risk factor. The clinical picture combines features of both chronic bronchitis (chronic productive cough for several years) and emphysema (progressive dyspnea). The physical examination findings, including an increased anteroposterior chest diameter (barrel chest), a prolonged expiratory phase, and diminished breath sounds, are hallmark signs of hyperinflation and severe airflow obstruction caused by loss of elastic recoil and small airway collapse. The diagnosis is confirmed with spirometry showing a post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.70.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is characterized by a chronic productive cough due to permanent dilation of the airways. However, it typically involves the production of large volumes of purulent, often foul-smelling sputum, rather than the white sputum described. Although there can be overlap, this patient's extensive smoking history and classic signs of emphysematous hyperinflation make another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although asthma is an obstructive lung disease, it is characterized by reversible airflow limitation and episodic symptoms, often including prominent wheezing. This patient's symptoms are chronic and relentlessly progressive, not episodic. Furthermore, the chronic productive cough and increased anteroposterior chest diameter are much more characteristic of an alternative diagnosis.
questions.hint: The combination of a major risk factor with the classic physical examination findings of air trapping and hyperinflation is suggestive of this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of worsening dyspnea and bilateral ankle swelling. He has a history of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he uses a tiotropium/olodaterol inhaler daily and albuterol as needed. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His oxygen saturation is 86% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension and 2+ pitting edema to the mid-shins. Auscultation shows a loud P2 and distant breath sounds with scattered expiratory wheezes. Which of the following interventions is most likely to improve this patient's long-term survival?

choices.text: Enrollment in a pulmonary rehabilitation program

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is the only intervention proven to increase survival in patients with severe resting hypoxemia due to COPD. Continuous administration (≥ 15 hours/day) improves 5‑year survival and decreases hospitalizations in chronic respiratory failure. The underlying cause of this patient's cor pulmonale is chronic hypoxemia (SpO2 of 86%), which leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction and hypertension. By correcting alveolar hypoxia, LTOT attenuates pulmonary vasoconstriction, slows the progression of pulmonary hypertension, and improves right ventricular function. Indications for LTOT include a resting partial pressure of arterial oxygen ≤ 55 mm Hg or an SpO2 ≤ 88%. Other interventions (e.g., lung volume reduction, transplantation) may improve quality of life, but no others have definitively shown a survival benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

A loop diuretic, such as furosemide, would be appropriate to manage the symptoms of volume overload (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distension) from this patient's right-sided heart failure. Although it can provide significant symptomatic relief by reducing preload, diuretic therapy does not address the underlying cause of cor pulmonale and has not been shown to improve long-term survival in this population.

C) INCORRECT:

Adding an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) to this patient's long-acting muscarinic antagonist/long-acting beta-agonist regimen is a consideration for patients with frequent COPD exacerbations or evidence of eosinophilic inflammation. Although ICS can reduce the frequency of exacerbations, large clinical trials have not shown a consistent long-term survival benefit. This intervention does not address this patient's chronic hypoxemia and cor pulmonale.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary rehabilitation is a critical component of comprehensive COPD management that improves exercise tolerance, dyspnea, and quality of life, while also reducing hospitalizations. However, despite these significant benefits, it has not been demonstrated to confer a direct long-term survival benefit. The question specifically asks for an intervention that improves mortality.

E) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that is sometimes used in patients with COPD and chronic bronchitis to reduce the frequency of exacerbations. However, its role in routine COPD management is not well-established, and it has not been shown to improve lung function, slow disease progression, or provide a long-term survival benefit.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with jugular venous distension, a loud P2, and peripheral edema in the context of severe COPD is typical for cor pulmonale.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a chronic productive cough. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. He appears comfortable at rest, but he became dyspneic when walking to the examination room. Physical examination shows prolonged expiration and diffuse, faint wheezes. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Dullness to percussion over the lung bases

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tactile fremitus refers to the vibration felt on the chest wall during speech and is increased when sound waves are transmitted more efficiently through a denser medium, such as in lobar pneumonia (consolidation). In COPD, hyperinflation leads to less dense lung tissue, which impedes sound transmission, characteristically causing decreased, not increased, tactile fremitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Dullness to percussion indicates increased density within the thoracic cavity, such as from consolidation (pneumonia) or fluid (pleural effusion). Although a patient with COPD may develop these complications, the characteristic percussion finding in uncomplicated COPD is hyperresonance due to air trapping.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation signifies a significant pressure or volume asymmetry between the two sides of the chest. It is seen in conditions such as a large pleural effusion, tension pneumothorax, or a large mediastinal mass. This is an emergency finding and is not a characteristic feature of the progressive, chronic changes seen in COPD.

D) CORRECT:

An increased anterior-posterior (AP) diameter of the chest, often referred to as a “barrel chest,” is one of the structural changes seen in individuals with COPD, especially in those with significant emphysematous changes. The destruction of alveolar elastic tissue in COPD leads to decreased elastic recoil and expiratory airflow limitation. This results in chronic air trapping and lung hyperinflation. Over time, the thoracic cage remodels to accommodate the chronically inflated lungs, leading to the increased AP diameter. Other associated findings include the use of accessory muscles for respiration, a flattened diaphragm on imaging, and hyperresonance to percussion.

E) INCORRECT:

Fine inspiratory crackles are typically caused by the sudden opening of small airways and alveoli that were collapsed during expiration. This finding is characteristic of conditions such as interstitial lung disease or pulmonary edema from heart failure. Although coarse crackles can sometimes be heard in the chronic bronchitis component of COPD due to secretions, fine crackles are not a typical finding.
questions.hint: This patient's significant smoking history, clinical presentation (exertional dyspnea and chronic productive cough), and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a several-year history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. He initially noticed it only with strenuous activity, but now becomes winded walking to his mailbox. He has a chronic morning cough productive of white sputum and a 45-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), his pulse is 88/min, and his respirations are 22/min. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. On examination, he has an increased anteroposterior chest diameter, decreased breath sounds bilaterally, and a prolonged expiratory phase. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to establish the diagnosis?

choices.text: Spirometry before and after bronchodilator administration
High-resolution computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The gold standard for diagnosing COPD is spirometry. This test measures the amount and speed of air that can be inhaled and exhaled. The key diagnostic criterion is a post-bronchodilator FEV1:FVC < 70%, which confirms persistent, largely irreversible airflow limitation. Administering a short-acting bronchodilator is crucial to differentiate COPD from asthma, as asthma typically shows significant reversibility of airflow obstruction. The severity of obstruction is then graded based on the post-bronchodilator FEV1 value.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency is a genetic cause of early-onset emphysema. While guidelines recommend screening all patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease for AAT deficiency, this test identifies a specific cause rather than establishing the primary diagnosis. This patient's advanced age and significant smoking history make smoking the most likely cause of his condition, although screening for AAT deficiency would be appropriate after the diagnosis is confirmed.

C) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is more sensitive than a chest x-ray for detecting emphysematous changes. However, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. HRCT is typically reserved for cases in which the diagnosis is uncertain, to evaluate for coexisting conditions such as bronchiectasis, or for preoperative planning for lung volume reduction surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is often performed in the initial evaluation of a patient with chronic dyspnea to exclude other conditions, such as lung cancer, interstitial lung disease, or heart failure. While it may show findings suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), such as hyperinflation, flattened diaphragms, and an increased retrosternal space, these findings are not sensitive or specific enough to establish the diagnosis. A normal chest x-ray does not rule out COPD.

It is useful for evaluating the severity of a patient's disease, particularly during an acute exacerbation or in advanced disease, in which it may show hypoxemia or chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. However, an ABG cannot be used to establish the diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
